description.narrative: Corruption is widely recognized as one of the biggest obstacles to development. Individuals and societies are deprived of their basic human rights due to corruption. Corruption occurs at all levels and in all sectors of society, e.g. on local and national authorities, civil society, the judiciary, large and small companies and the armed forces. Corruption makes it difficult for poor people to survive by forcing them to spend more of their already limited income on e.g. mutor. Corruption is both a cause of poverty and an obstacle to overcoming poverty. Corruption erodes international and domestic resources allocated to poverty reduction and consolidates the problem of poverty. Transparency International (TI), to which hundreds of national branches worldwide are affiliated, is headquartered in Berlin. Since its inception in 1993, TI has succeeded in its goal of putting corruption on the international agenda and has grown to become an international authority in areas related to corruption. Among TI's successes, it can be mentioned that both the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund now see corruption as one of the biggest threats to development. TI also played a major role in enforcing the UN Convention against Corruption and the OECD Convention against Bribery. TI publishes a number of publications annually, including a Global Corruption Report, a research report examining the prevalence of corruption in a number of countries worldwide, and a Corruption Perceptions Index, a recognized and established instrument for measuring the degree of corruption in a country. In the coming years, TI's work will be focused on: -Strengthening partnerships at all levels to increase accountability and expanding efforts to support victims of corruption, witnesses and whistleblowers. -Strengthening prevention, implementation and justice (including the fight against impunity), which will mean continued global and regional anti-corruption efforts and related campaigns with a greater focus on e.g. corrupt / illegal financial flows and corruption in politics. -Strengthening the TI movement (Berlin Secretariat and National Departments) which is expected to lead to a greater knowledge and understanding of effective measures in the fight against corruption - includes support for TI's National Departments and the strengthening of their capacity in areas such as governance, financial anti-corruption systems and leadership. -Strengthening the development and dissemination of innovative information, knowledge and tools to combat corruption.

Korruption är allmänt erkänt som ett av de största hindren för utveckling. Individer och samhällen berövas sina grundläggande mänskliga rättigheter på grund av korruption. Korruption förekommer på alla nivåer och i alla sektorer av samhället, t.ex. på lokala och nationella myndigheter, civila samhället, rättsväsendet, stora och mindre företag och försvarsmakten. Korruption försvårar för fattiga människor att överleva genom att tvinga dem att spendera mer av sina redan begränsade inkomster på t.ex. mutor. Korruption är både en orsak till fattigdom och ett hinder i att övervinna fattigdom. Korruption urholkar internationella och inhemska resurser som är allokerade för fattigdomsbekämpning och befäster fattigdomsproblemet.
Transparency International (TI), till vilken ett hundratal nationella avdelningar världen över är anslutna, har sitt säte i Berlin. Sedan grundandet 1993 har TI lyckats i sin målsättning att sätta korruption på den internationella agendan och har vuxit till att bli en internationell auktoritet på områden som rör korruption. Bland TI:s framgångar kan nämnas att såväl Världsbanken som Internationella valutafonden numera ser korruption som ett av de största hoten mot utveckling. TI spelade också en stor roll i att genomdriva FN:s konvention mot korruption och OECD:s konvention mot mutor. TI ger årligen ut ett antal publikationer, däribland en Global Corruption Report, en forskningsrapport som undersöker förekomsten av korruption i ett antal länder världen över, och ett Corruption Perceptions Index, ett erkänt och etablerat instrument för att mäta graden av korruption i ett land.
TI:s arbete kommer under de kommande åren vara fokuserat på: -Stärkandet av partnerskap på alla plan för att öka ansvarsutkrävande och utvidgandet av arbetet med att stödja korruptionens offer, vittnen och visselblåsare. -Stärkandet av prevention, genomförande och rättvisa (inklusive bekämpandet av straffrihet), vilket kommer att innebära fortsatt globalt och regionalt anti-korruptionspåverkansarbete och relaterade kampanjer med större fokus på bl.a. korrupta/illegala finansiella flöden och korruption inom politiken. -Stärkandet av TI rörelsen (sekretariatet i Berlin och nationella avdelningar) som förväntas leda till en större kunskap om och förståelse för effektiva åtgärder i bekämpandet av korruption - inkluderar stöd till TI:s nationella avdelningar och stärkandet av deras kapacitet inom områden såsom samhällsstyrning, finansiella system och ledarskap för korruptionsbekämpning. -Stärkandet av utvecklingen och spridningen av innovativ information, kunskap och redskap för att bekämpa korruption.

Transparency International (TI) is a global anti-corruption movement. Tl's vision is a world in which government, business, civil society and the daily lives of people are free from corruption. TI is made up of more than 100 chapters worldwide, individual members, and an international Secretariat in Berlin. Since 1993, TI has campaigned for greater transparency and accountability in government and business. TI's mission is to stop corruption and promote transparency, accountability and integrity at all levels and across all sectors of society. The guiding document for the TI movement is the strategy 2020 "Together against corruption", which is implemented for the period 2016 to 2020. Sida’s support is to the TI Secretariat (TI-S) and for its lead in implementing the strategy 2020. Support to TI-S work is expected to contribute to the realization of the SDGs, especially goal 16 on good governance.

description.narrative: TI has reported progress over the last years. During 2019 and 2020 it is particularly interesting to highlight a few focus areas: TI raises its two global prioriteis, Dirty Money and Political Interity and shows the lobbying work that is being done. Some success can be seen as the EU has adopted a directive on whistleblower protection where many of TI's recommendations were included in the agreed text. Also, TI lobby work resulted in that the European Commission’s supranational risk assessment report identified the "golden visa" industry as a sector that poses money laundering and terrorist financing risks to the EU. It will now be monitored. Cyprus and Malta now face legal actions and Cyprus has suspended its golden visa program. TI secured an appraisal of recommendations on beneficial ownership transparency in the Financial Action Task Force’s (FATF) strategic review. TI's Advocacy and Legal Advice Centers (ALACs) provided free and confidential legal advice to witnesses and victims of corruption in more than 60 countries. Examples are mentioned such as TI Bosnia and Hercegovina who won 30 administrative disputes in the courts against various government ministries that were infringing the law on free access to information, based on data gathered by ALAC. 2019 was the first year when the Global Corruption Barometer for the Middle East and North Africa and for Latin America and the Carribean included specific questions to help better understand the impact of corruption on women. This allowed TI to collect data on sextortion. TI supported Chapters to actively participate in the Open Government Partnership co-creation of National Action Plans. Through mini grants, the secretariat helped Chapters to strengthen their processes and combine earning with action and stakeholder interaction.
